leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.6] r 14.6 Pleadings to be divided into paragraphs (cf SCR Part 15, rule 6; DCR Part 9, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings to be divided into paragraphs (cf SCR Part 15, rule 6; DCR Part 9, rule 2)

p.text: If a pleading alleges or otherwise deals with several matters:
the pleading must be divided into paragraphs, and
each matter must, so far as convenient, be put in a separate paragraph, and
the paragraphs must be numbered consecutively.

This is an important requirement with potentially significant ramifications for the definition of contested issues and the efficient conduct of the proceedings. However, the apparent simplicity of the requirement, together with the inherent qualification implied by the use of the expression “so far as convenient”, belies the difficulty of achieving an appropriate degree of compliance. The difficulty is compounded by the need to observe the distinction between material facts and evidence, and also the distinction between matters of fact and matters of law. Unless those distinctions are borne constantly in mind, there is a tendency for pleadings to fall into a style that combines, in the same paragraph, distinct factual allegations with alternative allegations as to their legal significance. Scrupulous adherence to the requirements of the present rule will assist a plaintiff by demanding careful analysis and expression of the individual ingredients of the causes of action relied upon, and identification of the essential material facts available to establish them. Furthermore, the separation of material allegations may enhance a plaintiff’s prospect of obtaining admissions of particular facts and should, in any event, lead to a precise identification of the real matters in issue. In the pleading of a defence, compliance with the present rule is no less important. Each traverse of the plaintiff’s allegations should be specifically pleaded in a separate paragraph. If inconsistent defences are pleaded in the alternative, the facts material to each of them ought be stated in separate paragraphs. Specific defences, including positive allegations of material facts relied upon by the defendant, should not be mixed up with mere traverses or merely insinuated: see Belt v Lawes (1882) 51 LJQB 359 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.7] r 14.7 Pleadings to contain facts, not evidence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 7; DCR Part 9, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings to contain facts, not evidence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 7; DCR Part 9, rule 3)

p.text: Subject to this Part, Part 6 and Part 15 , a party’s pleading must contain only a summary of the material facts on which the party relies, and not the evidence by which those facts are to be proved.

The requirement that a pleading contain a summary does not detract from the requirement to be brief, distinguish between material facts and evidence, use separate paragraphs, assert only the effect of documents and to plead specifically matters which might otherwise cause surprise to the opposing party. Consequently, the style and content of the summary of facts will depend on the complementary application of all the pleading rules to the circumstances of the particular case.

The requirement to plead facts and not evidence (Blake v Albion Life Assurance Society (1876) 45 LJQB 663 at 667 ; Phillips v Phillips (1878) 4 QBD 127 at 133 ; North Western Salt Co Ltd v Electrolytic Alkali Co Ltd [1913] 3 KB 422 at 425 ; Merchants & Manufacturers Insurance Co Ltd v Davies [1938] 1 KB 196 ) implies a distinction that is more easily stated than consistently and properly applied: Re Dependable Upholstery Ltd [1936] 3 All ER 741 . The fundamental idea is the distinction between primary facts and those that are merely relevant or evidentiary. Some indication of the nature of the intended distinction can be gained by consideration of some examples. A simple example concerns out of court admissions. The pleader should allege the fact that has been admitted, not the fact that the admission was made — the former is the primary fact and the later merely evidence. Another different example arises where a party is a trustee of property. It is generally sufficient to plead the allegation in those simple terms without setting out the facts that give rise to the trust, although particulars may be necessary: Miller v Registrar-General (1926) 43 WN (NSW) 135 ; Scarf v Lohan (NSWSC, Cohen M, 26 April 1979, unreported). The facts pleaded should be pleaded with precision and not left to be inferred from vague or ambiguous expressions or from general statements of circumstances that are consistent with different conclusions: see Bullen and Leake and Jacob's Precedents of Pleading 12th ed, 1975, Sweet and Maxwell, p 35. Consequently, the requirement to plead facts is not satisfied merely by referring to the existence of documents and claiming to rely upon them as justifying a particular conclusion: Phillips v Phillips (1878) 4 QBD 127 . The requirement that the pleader must state “facts” means that it is not sufficient to assert conclusions of law, arguments, reasons, theories, conclusions or mere matters of prediction: East West Airlines (Operations) Ltd v Commonwealth (1983) 49 ALR 323; BC8300108 . In an action in negligence, for example, it is not sufficient for the plaintiff to plead general phrases referable to the tort, thereby leaving the defendant to establish why those general formulae would be insufficient to enable the plaintiff to be successful in the proceedings: Ashrafi Persian Trading Co Pty Ltd (t/as Roslyn Gardens Motor Inn) v Ashrafinaia (2002) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-636; [2001] NSWCA 243; BC200104223 .

The circumstances of each case will determine what facts are material. All facts on which the cause of action or defence depend are material: Darbyshire v Leigh [1896] 1 QB 554 ; Re Rica Gold Washing Co (1879) 11 Ch D 36 ; Belmont Finance Corp Ltd v Williams Furniture Ltd [1979] 1 Ch 250; [1979] 1 All ER 118 ; Kirby v Sanderson Motors Pty Ltd (2001) 54 NSWLR 135; [2002] NSWCA 44; BC200200586 . Whether the material facts have been pleaded can generally be determined by asking if the claim or defence would be made out if all of the pleaded allegations were admitted: Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (No 20) (1988) 14 NSWLR 124 at 126 . Allegations may be material even though they are not essential to the cause of action: Gaston v United Newspapers Ltd (1915) 32 TLR 143 at 144 ; Millington v Loring (1880) 6 QBD 190 at 193, 195 . Matters that go to aggravation of damages or, in the case of a defence, mitigation of damages, are material and should be pleaded: Plato Films Ltd v Speidel [1961] AC 1090; [1961] 1 All ER 876 ; Goody v Odhams Press Ltd [1967] 1 QB 333 ; cf Wilson v Dun’s Gazette Ltd [1912] VLR 342 . But matters of confession and avoidance of an expected defence are not material and should be left to the plaintiff’s reply: Hall v Eve (1876) 4 Ch D 341 at 345, 348 ; and see Bullen and Leake and Jacob's Precedent of Pleadings 12th ed, 1975, Sweet and Maxwell, p 71. Matters that go merely to the question of costs are not material: Ricketts v Fraser (1886) 8 ALT 21 ; Sundercombe v Stubb (1889) 15 VLR 509 . If a fact is material it must be pleaded. It is not sufficient merely to refer to it in the particulars: H 1976 Nominees Pty Ltd v Galli (1979) 30 ALR 181 at 186–7; 40 FLR 242 ; Truth about Motorways Pty Ltd v Macquarie Infrastructure Investment Management Ltd (1998) ATPR ¶41-633; Bruce v Odhams Press Ltd [1936] 1 KB 697 at 712 ; Rubenstein v Truth & Sportsman Ltd [1960] VR 473 at 476 ; Papps v Mahon [1966] NZLR 288 at 292 ; Halsbury’s Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 36, paras 11–16. (If a fact is referred to only in particulars, there is no requirement for the opposing party to plead to it: Trade Practices Commission v David Jones (Aust) Pty Ltd (1985) 7 FCR 109.)

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.8] r 14.8 Pleadings to be brief (cf SCR Part 15, rule 8; DCR Part 9, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings to be brief (cf SCR Part 15, rule 8; DCR Part 9, rule 4)

p.text: A pleading must be as brief as the nature of the case allows.

Pleadings ought to be precise and concise, clear and definite (Re Parton; Townsend v Parton (1882) 30 WR 287 ), and a pleading that fails to comply with this requirement may be struck out: Hill v Hart-Davis (1884) 26 Ch D 470 . However, the circumstance that the material facts are stated at great length will not ordinarily justify the striking out of the statement of claim. Similarly, it is probably also correct to say that a statement of claim should not be struck out merely because it includes allegations of non-material facts, unless the pleading as a whole is such as to embarrass the defendant in being able to appreciate the precise nature of the plaintiff’s case: Davy v Garrett (1877) 7 Ch D 473 at 488 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.9] r 14.9 References in pleadings to documents and spoken words (cf SCR Part 15, rule 9; DCR Part 9, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: References in pleadings to documents and spoken words (cf SCR Part 15, rule 9; DCR Part 9, rule 5)

p.text: If any documents or spoken words are referred to in a pleading:
the effect of the document or spoken words must, so far as material, be stated, and
the precise terms of the document or spoken words must not be stated, except so far as those terms are themselves material.

level.toc-caption: [14.9.5] The effect, not the content, of statements and documents

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: The effect, not the content, of statements and documents

p.text: This rule should be seen as an adjunct to the requirement to plead material facts and is consistent with the distinction (referred to in [14.7.10] ) between material facts and evidence. It is just one of the several provisions of this Part that are intended to encourage pleadings to identify the real issues to be determined in the proceedings. Even before this rule, unless the effect of a document was set out in the pleading, it could not be read on a motion to strike out the statement of claim: Howard v Hill [1887] WN 193; (1887) 4 TLR 20; Williamson v London & North Western Railway Co (1879) 12 Ch D 787 ; Smith v Buchan (1875) 36 WR 631; 58 LT 710. But the present rule goes further and positively requires that the terms of a document or statement shall not be included in the pleading unless, and only to the extent that, particular terms are material: Borradaile v Hunter (1843) 5 Man & G 639; 134 ER 715. It is therefore contrary to the rules, although it is a practice that is sometimes encountered, for a pleading merely to refer to the existence or contents of a document and foreshadow an intention to rely upon its contents: Phillips v Phillips (1878) 4 QBD 127 . This practice, whether encountered in a statement of claim or in a defence renders the document liable to be struck out: TCS ACES Pty Ltd v Mikohn Gaming Australasia Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1139; BC200708818 at [7] . Such a pleading does not comply with the fundamental requirement to plead material facts and not evidence. It potentially involves several adverse consequences. First, it betrays a lack of confidence in appreciating the true effect of the statement or document. Second, it probably fails to comply with the party’s obligations under s 56 of the CPA. Third, it has the disadvantage that no specific admission can be obtained in response to such an allegation. Fourth, on an application to strike out the pleading, no reliance could be placed on the contents of the document (Metropolitan Theatres Ltd v Harris (1935) 35 SR (NSW) 228 at 233 ; Thompson v Randwick Municipal Council (1953) 90 CLR 449 at 457; [1953] ALR 117 ); (Wagstaff v Fitzpatrick (1922) 39 WN (NSW) 137 ; Kelly v Mawson [1981] 1 NSWLR 184; (1981) 5 ACLR 600 ), that is, unless the relevant document or statement was specifically put into evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.10] r 14.10 Certain facts need not be pleaded (cf SCR Part 15, rule 10; DCR Part 9, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Certain facts need not be pleaded (cf SCR Part 15, rule 10; DCR Part 9, rule 6)

p.text: A party need not plead a fact if:
the fact is presumed by law to be true, or
the burden of disproving the fact lies on the opposite party,
except so far as may be necessary to meet a specific denial of that fact by another party’s pleading.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.11] r 14.11 Conditions precedent presumed to have been met (cf SCR Part 15, rule 11; DCR Part 9, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Conditions precedent presumed to have been met (cf SCR Part 15, rule 11; DCR Part 9, rule 7)

p.text: If it is a condition precedent necessary for a party’s case in any pleading that:
a thing has been done, or
an event has happened, or
a state of affairs exists, or has existed at some time or times, or
the party is ready and willing, or was at all material times ready and willing, to perform an obligation,
a statement to the effect that the condition has been satisfied is taken to be implied in the party’s pleading.

The effect of this rule is that a pleading is to be construed as if it contains an implied allegation of the due performance of any conditions precedent to which the rule applies: Galluzzi v Linfox Transport (Aust) Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland CJ in Eq, 15 June 1995, unreported, BC9504824); Dalswinton Pastoral Company Pty Ltd v Cole [2006] NSWSC 570; BC200604270 at [5] (allegation of willingness to complete in specific performance suit). However, and despite the terms of the rule, where the relevant allegation is an essential ingredient of the cause of action (such as the making of a demand in detinue, or notice of dishonour in the case of a bill of exchange), it must still be pleaded: May v Chidley [1894] 1 QB 451 ; Roberts v Plant [1895] 1 QB 597 . Similarly, if the plaintiff is an assignee, the material details of the assignment must be pleaded: Seear v Lawson (1880) 16 Ch D 121 . And a similar allegation must be pleaded by a trust beneficiary who brings proceedings on behalf of a trustee: Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2005] NSWSC 482; BC200503384 . A defendant who wishes to allege non-performance of a condition precedent must specifically plead that allegation and the terms of the condition: Abbs v Matheson & Co (1898) 104 LT Jo 268. But, once the matter has been put in issue in the proceedings, the present rule does not affect the onus of proof at the trial: Gates v WA & RJ Jacobs Ltd [1920] 1 Ch 567 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.12] r 14.12 Pleading of facts in short form in certain money claims (cf SCR Part 15, rule 12; DCR Part 9, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Pleading of facts in short form in certain money claims (cf SCR Part 15, rule 12; DCR Part 9, rule 8)

p.text: Subject to this rule, if the plaintiff claims money payable by the defendant to the plaintiff for any of the following:
goods sold and delivered by the plaintiff to the defendant,
goods bargained and sold by the plaintiff to the defendant,
work done or materials provided by the plaintiff for the defendant at the defendant’s request,
money lent by the plaintiff to the defendant,
money paid by the plaintiff for the defendant at the defendant’s request,
money had and received by the defendant for the plaintiff’s use,
interest on money due from the defendant to the plaintiff, and forborne at interest by the plaintiff at the defendant’s request,

money found to be due from the defendant to the plaintiff on accounts stated between them, it is sufficient to plead the facts concerned in short form (that is, by using the form of words set out in the relevant paragraph above).
The defendant may file a notice requiring the plaintiff to plead the facts on which he or she relies in full (that is, in accordance with the provisions of this Part other than this rule).
Such a notice must be filed within the time limited for the filing of the defence.
If the defendant files a notice under this rule:
the plaintiff must, within 28 days after service of the notice:
file an amended statement of claim pleading the facts on which he or she relies in full, and
include in the amended statement of claim a note to the effect that the statement has been amended in response to the notice, and
if a defence has not been filed, the time limited for the filing of defence is extended until 14 days after service on the defendant of the plaintiff’s amended statement of claim.
The approved form is Form 16 : Notice to plead facts — money claims.

This rule allows the old common money counts to be used in a statement of liquidated claim. However, the nature of the claim should be particularised and the particulars should include proper details showing how the amount claimed is made up: Lazar v Williamson (1884) 1 WN (NSW) 33; George Patterson Pty Ltd v James Wallace Pty Ltd [1964–5] NSWR 1299; Astronaut Travel Service Pty Ltd v Premier-Premal Pty Ltd (1973) 3 DCR (NSW) 225; see also [15.1.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.13] r 14.13 Pleading not to claim an amount for unliquidated damages (cf SCR Part 15, rule 12A; LCR Part 5, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Pleading not to claim an amount for unliquidated damages (cf SCR Part 15, rule 12A; LCR Part 5, rule 1)

p.text: A pleading must not claim an amount for unliquidated damages.
Despite subrule (1), a pleading in proceedings in the Local Court may claim an amount for unliquidated damages if:
the claim is for the recovery of:
the cost of repair to a motor vehicle, or
the value, less any salvage value, of a motor vehicle, or
the towing of a motor vehicle, or
the cost of hiring a replacement car,
where the repair, loss, towing or cost of hiring is a consequence of damage alleged to have been sustained as a result of the negligence of the defendant or the defendant’s servant or agent, or
the claim is for the recovery of:
the cost of repair to property other than a motor vehicle, or
the value, less any salvage value, of property other than a motor vehicle,

where the repair or loss is a consequence of damage alleged to have been sustained as a result of the negligence of the defendant or the defendant’s servant or agent in driving, riding or controlling a motor vehicle.
[subr (2) am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009 ; Amendment 57 of 2013 Sch 1[1]–[3], effective 8 March 2013]

In subrule (2), a reference to a motor vehicle is a reference to a motor vehicle within the meaning of the Motor Accidents Compensation Act 1999, and includes a reference to a trailer within the meaning of that Act.
Legislation cited in [14.13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.13(2), r 16.6, r 16.7.

UCPR r 14.13(2) permits default judgment for unliquidated damages in Local Court or District Court proceedings, if the damages are confined to the value of a motor vehicle or expenses related to its repair. Any such application for default judgment must be supported by an affidavit complying with UCPR r 16.6 . If the claim relates to other categories of unliquidated damages the only available default judgment is for costs and for damages to be assessed. An application of that kind must be supported by an affidavit that complies with UCPR r 16.7 . Any default judgment entered otherwise than in compliance with those requirements is liable to be set aside as irregular: see Monkton v Stephenson [2011] NSWSC 67; BC201103168 at [66] and [67].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.14] r 14.14 General rule as to matters to be pleaded specifically (cf SCR Part 15, rule 13; DCR Part 9, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: General rule as to matters to be pleaded specifically (cf SCR Part 15, rule 13; DCR Part 9, rule 9)

p.text: In a statement of claim, the plaintiff must plead specifically any matter that, if not pleaded specifically, may take the defendant by surprise.
In a defence or subsequent pleading, a party must plead specifically any matter:
that, if not pleaded specifically, may take the opposite party by surprise, or
that the party alleges makes any claim, defence or other case of the opposite party not maintainable, or
that raises matters of fact not arising out of the preceding pleading.

Matters which must be pleaded pursuant to subrule (2) include (but are not limited to) fraud, performance, release, statute of limitation, extinction of right or title, voluntary assumption of risk, causation of accident by unknown and undiscoverable mechanical defect and facts showing illegality.

level.toc-caption: [14.14.5] The requirement for specific pleading — a particular application of a wider principle

heading.title: The requirement for specific pleading — a particular application of a wider principle

p.text: The requirement for specific pleading, particularly of any matters that might take the other party by surprise, complements many other rules designed to define the matters in issue and promote the “just, quick and cheap” disposal of proceedings. The purpose of the specific pleading requirement is to ensure that material facts are stated in such a way that each opposing party has a proper opportunity to fully appreciate their materiality to the cause of action: Kirby v Sanderson Motors Pty Ltd (2001) 54 NSWLR 135; [2002] NSWCA 44; BC200200586 . It is also to preclude parties from merely traversing the other’s allegations where the party’s true case involves either some positive assertion of fact, some special claim (such as a statutory cause of action or defence) or a claim that the other party’s case is bad in law: Attorney-General v Lord Mayor of Sheffıeld (1912) 106 LT 367 : Zisis v Knighton [2008] NSWCA 42; BC200802110 at [48]–[50] , noted at [LCA07 s 29.5] and [LCA07 s 29.10] (asserted lack of jurisdiction not raised as an issue until final addresses). The fundamental purpose of the requirement is to give each party proper opportunity to prepare and present its case: Bright v Sampson & Duncan Enterprises Pty Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 346 ; Re Robinson’s Settlement; Gant v Hobbs [1912] 1 Ch 717 at 728 . The philosophy underlying the purpose of the requirement is that the interests of justice are best served by ensuring the real issues in dispute are litigated in a proper, timely and efficient manner. The ramifications of this philosophy for the proper conduct of litigation are illustrated in the observations of Allsop J in White v Overland [2001] FCA 1333; BC200105643 at [4] . Allsop J said:

... the parties should take steps to ensure that all relevant parties to the dispute are cognisant of what the issues are... where it is evident, or indeed suspected, that the other side is proceeding on the basis of a misconception or has not appreciated something, as a general rule, efficiency, common sense and an appreciation of the costs and resources (both public and private) likely to be wasted by confusion in litigation will mandate that a party... ensure that the other is not proceeding on a misconception or that the other does appreciate something that has been said. Litigation is not a game. It is a costly and stressful, though necessary, evil. To paraphrase Roscoe Pound from “The Causes of Popular Dissatisfaction with the Administration of Justice” (1906) 29 ABA Rep 395 at 404–6, the “sporting theory of justice” and any behavioural manifestation of it should be seen as a survival, or better, a relic, of the days when a lawsuit was a fight between two clans: cf Jackamarra v Krakouer (1998) 195 CLR 516 at 526–7; 153 ALR 276 at 283–4; [1998] HCA 27; BC9801285 per Gummow and Hayne JJ. Representatives do not owe duties to the other side’s client. They owe duties to their own client. But no one’s interests are advanced by litigation proceeding on assumptions which are seen or suspected to be false... In the long run, the only consequence of keeping issues hidden or not clearly identifying them is to disrupt the business of the court leading to the waste of valuable public resources and to lead to the incurring of unnecessary costs by the parties...

The same point is illustrated by the decisions in Nowlan v Marson Transport Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 116; 34 MVR 495; [2001] NSWCA 346; BC200105900 and Malone v New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service [2001] NSWCA 345; BC200105899 , where the Court of Appeal explicitly approved Allsop J’s comments and allowed an appeal on the basis of further evidence on a factual issue that had not been specifically put in contest at the hearing below. See also Glover v Australian Ultra Concrete Floors Pty Ltd [2003] NSWCA 80; BC200301878 (corroborative further evidence admitted on appeal, to rebut oral evidence of fabrication). In Baulderstone Hornibrook Engineering Pty Ltd v Gordian Runoff Ltd [2008] NSWCA 243; BC200808862 at [162]–[165] , Allsop P again emphasised the need for clarity, precision and openness in delineating the issues in a long and complex Commercial List trial. See also comments by Ipp JA in Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Market Ltds (2008) 252 ALR 659; 68 ACSR 595; [2008] NSWCA 206; BC200810804 at [417]–[421] and [435]–[443] (appellants were required to plead specifically any part of their case that relied on lack of integrity and materiality of misleading or deceptive conduct claimed).

level.toc-caption: [14.14.10] Matters for specific pleading — general examples

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.14.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.16.

heading.title: Matters for specific pleading — general examples

p.text: UCPR r 14.14(3) makes it clear that the specific pleading requirement is purposive and not limited to specific categories of either factual allegations or points that give rise to a defence in law. Consistent with that view, there is a wide range of examples where the courts have required specific pleading. The plaintiff should plead matters relied upon in aggravation of damages: Millington v Loring (1880) 6 QBD 190 ; Whitney v Moignard (1890) 24 QBD 630 . All matters of justification or excuse must be specially pleaded (Attorney-General v Lord Mayor of Sheffıeld (1912) 106 LT 367 ; Johnstone v Pedlar [1921] 2 AC 262 ); Sydney South West Area Health Service v MD (2009) 260 ALR 702; [2009] NSWCA 343; BC200909477 at [20]–[24], [51], [61]–[64] (professional standards — reliance on s 5O of the Civil Liability Act 2002; so must all defences of illegality or nullity: Thorby v Goldberg (1964) 112 CLR 597 at 617; BC6400700 ; Davie v New Merton Board Mills [1956] 1 All ER 379; [1956] 1 WLR 233 ; Castles v Freidman (1910) 11 CLR 580; 17 ALR 181 (defence under money lending legislation); Re Robinson’s Settlement; Gant v Hobbs [1912] 1 Ch 717 (moneylending legislation defence). Estoppel must be pleaded: Coppinger v Norton [1902] 2 Ir R 232. A defence of statutory authority must be pleaded: Coburn v Collins (1887) 35 Ch D 373 ; Hayward v Lely (1887) 56 LT 418 . Release must be pleaded: Proudfoot v Stubbens (1886) 2 WN (NSW) 46. Payment must be pleaded: Young v Queensland Trustees Ltd (1956) 99 CLR 560; [1956] ALR 939; BC5600800 . Other matters which should be specially pleaded include a defence of non est factum (Gallie v Lee [1971] AC 1004; [1970] 3 WLR 1078 ); a defence raising the Statute of Frauds or its modern equivalents (Clarke v Callow (1876) 46 LJQB 53 ; Olley v Fisher (1886) 34 Ch D 367 ); an allegation of fundamental breach: Hunt & Winterbottom (West of England) Ltd v RRS (Parcels) Ltd [1962] 1 QB 617 ; republication in defamation proceedings: Sims v Wran [1984] 1 NSWLR 317 ; equitable interests: Oliveri v Jones (NSWSC, Bryson J, 18 December 1996, unreported, BC9606271). Contributory negligence must be specially pleaded: r 14.16 of the UCPR. The burden of proving a failure to mitigate lies on the defendant: Wenkart v Pitman (1998) 46 NSWLR 502; BC9805107 ; TCN Channel 9 Pty Ltd v Hayden Enterprises Pty Ltd (1989) 16 NSWLR 130 at 158; BC8902190 ; Joseph & Co v Harvest Grain Co (1996) 39 NSWLR 722 at 738 . Accordingly, failure to mitigate damages should be pleaded — at least where the matters relied upon go beyond matters alleged in the plaintiff’s claim: Plato Films Ltd v Speidel [1961] AC 1090 at 1105, 1145; [1961] 1 All ER 876 .
Legislation cited in [14.14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.28.

The requirement for specific pleading applies to allegations of fact relied on to establish common law or equitable estoppel: Laws Holdings Pty Ltd v Short (1972) 46 ALJR 563 at 571 ; Commissioner for Railways v Bielewicz [1963] NSWR 482 at 486; [1963] SR (NSW) 466 at 468 . Where these kinds of estoppel are relied on, the requirement for specific pleading is simply an illustration of the role of pleadings in de[filig ]ning the issues to be determined at the final hearing of the proceedings. However, other kinds of estoppel operate differently and, in effect, preclude the determination of certain matters in the proceedings. Estoppels of these kinds include cause of action estoppel (the principle of res judicata) and issue estoppel. Where a party intends to rely on a prior judgment as giving rise to a cause of action estoppel, the judgment should be specifically pleaded: Withers v Greenwood (1878) 4 VLR (L) 491 ; Houstoun v Marquis of Sligo (1885) 29 Ch D 448 ; Edevain v Cohen (1889) 43 Ch D 187 . But often the appropriate course of action will also involve not only the specific pleading required by the present rule, but also an application under r 14.28 to strike out the claim to which the estoppel relates: see further [14.28.5] (abuse of process), [14.28.15] (Res judicata) and [14.28.17] (Issue estoppel).

Where a matter of foreign law is to be relied on, or where it is to be alleged that foreign words are to be understood in a particular way, then this is a clear situation where the other party may be taken by surprise. Accordingly matters of that kind must be pleaded specifically: Ascherberg Hopwood & Crew Ltd v Casa Musicale [1971] 3 All ER 38; [1971] 1 WLR 1128 ; Regie National des Usines Renault SA v Zhang (2002) 187 ALR 1; 23 NSWCCR 207; [2002] HCA 10; BC200200802 at [70]–[72] .

For the purposes of this rule “fraud” includes, but is not confined to, allegations based on a cause of action in the tort of deceit. It includes a defendant’s allegations that the plaintiff’s claim is itself fraudulent because it involves allegations of fact that are known to be untrue: Ghazal v GIO (NSW) (1992) 29 NSWLR 336 . It also extends to include a plaintiff’s allegations of fraud made in response to a defence based upon the Limitation Act: Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 ; Lawrance v Lord Norreys (1890) 15 App Cas 210; [1886–90] All ER Rep 858 ; Bulli Coal Mining Co v Osborne [1899] AC 351 .

Whatever the particular context, any allegations of fraud must be clearly pleaded and properly particularised: Krakowski v Eurolynx Properties Ltd (1995) 183 CLR 563 at 573; 130 ALR 1 at 8; BC9506428 . Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 285; 92 ALR 53; BC9002932 ; Rajski v Bainton (1990) 22 NSWLR 125 at 135; BC9001557 ; Wallingford v Mutual Society (1880) LR 5 App Cas 685 at 697; Pickin v British Railways Board [1972] 3 All ER 923; [1973] QB 219 at 229; [1972] 3 WLR 824 ; Leitch v Abbott (1886) 31 Ch D 374 (discovery ordered to allow fraud to be fully pleaded). The pleading must specifically allege the acts involved and that they were done in a manner that involves fraud: Redgrave v Hurd (1882) 20 Ch D 1 at 12; [1881–5] All ER Rep 77; (1881) 45 LT 485 per Jessel MR; Lawrance v Norreys (1890) 15 App Cas 210 at 221; [1886–90] All ER Rep 858 — although it is not necessary to use the specific word “fraud”: Banque Commerciale SA (in liq) v Akhil Holdings Ltd (1990) 169 CLR 279 at 285, 295; 92 ALR 53 at 65; BC9002932 ; Johnston v ANZ Banking Group Ltd [2003] NSWSC 454 at [26]ff; BC200302917 ; Reddaway & Co v Bannam & Co [1896] AC 199 at 219; (1896) 1B IPR 401; [1895–99] All ER Rep 133 ; Angelides v James Stedman Henderson's Sweets Ltd (1927) 40 CLR 43 at 82; [1927] ALR 427; (1927) 1 ALJR 189a ; Middleton v O'Neill (1943) 43 SR (NSW) 178; 60 WN (NSW) 101 . For example, if it is alleged that there are false entries in books, particulars will be required to identify the entries, the respect in which they are inaccurate and the basis of the allegation that their inaccuracy was known: Newport (Mon) Slipway Dry Dock & Engineering Co v Paynter (1886) 34 Ch D 88 ; see also Arnold v Bottomley [1908] 2 KB 151 .

Whatever the precise context, no fraud allegation should ever be made unless the parties alleging fraud, and their legal representatives, are satisfied that it is in proper form and has a proper basis: see Ghazal v GIO (NSW) (1992) 29 NSWLR 336 . See also Associated Leisure Ltd (Phonographic Equipment Co Ltd) v Associated Newspapers Ltd [1970] 2 QB 450 at 456; [1970] 2 All ER 754 at 757–8; [1970] 3 WLR 101 ; Protean (Holdings) Ltd (recs and mgrs apptd) v American Home Assurance Co [1985] VR 187 at 213, 234 ; Perkins Maritime International Pty Ltd v Commonwealth Bank (1991) 105 FLR 216 at 221 (SC(NT)); White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd v Flower & Hart (a firm) (1998) 156 ALR 169 at 241–2; 29 ACSR 21; BC9803173 (FCA); Medcalf v Mardell [2003] 1 AC 120; [2002] 3 All ER 721; [2002] 3 WLR 172 . (However, this requirement for a proper basis does not mean that the party alleging fraud must have a positive belief that the allegation will actually succeed at a contested hearing: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1995) 57 FCR 360 .) The court will not give relief on an issue involving fraud unless the allegation has been clearly raised in the pleadings: Webster v Power (1868) LR 2 PC 69; see also Davy v Garrett (1877) 7 Ch D 473 at 489 ; Blay v Pollard & Morris [1930] 1 KB 628 at 634 ; J Earle Hermann Ltd v Ferry (1915) 32 WN (NSW) 31 ; Middleton v O’Neill (1943) 43 SR (NSW) 178; 60 WN (NSW) 101 ; Ritter v Northside Enterprises Pty Ltd (1975) 132 CLR 301; 6 ALR 125; BC7500029 ; Minister for Crown Lands v Tweed Byron Local Aboriginal Land Council (1990) 71 LGRA 201; BC9002479 ; and actually pursued at the hearing: see Permanent Trustee Australia Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (in liq) (2003) 197 ALR 364; [2003] HCA 25; BC200302168 at [38] .

level.toc-caption: [14.14.30] Relief or defences not specifically claimed

heading.title: Relief or defences not specifically claimed

p.text: Despite this rule, a judge may give effect in proper cases to defences which are not pleaded: Price v Richardson [1927] 1 KB 448 at 453 ; Sykes v Stratton [1972] 1 NSWLR 145 . But a judge is not required to give effect to defences that have not been contended for by parties. For example, except in exceptional cases, a trial judge is not required to consider a defence of illegality that has not been raised by the defendant: North Western Salt Co Ltd v Electrolytic Alkali Co Ltd [1914] AC 461 at 469; (1914) 30 TLR 313 ; Knowles v Fuller (1948) 48 SR (NSW) 243 at 245; Staniland v Kentucky Homes Pty Ltd [1988] NSWJB 17; BC8700903 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.15] r 14.15 Pleadings concerning possession of land (cf SCR Part 15, rule 15)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings concerning possession of land (cf SCR Part 15, rule 15)

p.text: This rule applies to proceedings on a claim for possession of land.
The plaintiff must plead specifically the following matters:
the nature of any instrument (such as a certificate of title, conveyance, will, trust instrument, mortgage or lease) from which the plaintiff’s claim is alleged to be derived,

if any such instrument is alleged to impose an obligation on the defendant whose breach has given rise to the plaintiff’s claim (such as an obligation to pay money to the plaintiff), the existence of that obligation and the occurrence of any such breach,

if any such instrument is alleged to confer a right on the plaintiff that vests at a specified time or is contingent on the occurrence of a specified event, the existence of that right and the occurrence of any such time or event,

if the plaintiff’s right to possession arises from the defendant’s failure to pay money to the plaintiff, particulars of the date on which the failure began, the amount of money currently unpaid and the method by which that amount has been calculated,
if the plaintiff’s right to possession arises from any other act or omission by the defendant, particulars of the date on which the act or omission occurred and the nature of the act or omission,

if the plaintiff’s right to possession is not exercisable until the plaintiff has given notice to the defendant of the plaintiff’s intention to exercise that right, the date on which, and the terms in which, such notice was given.
The defendant must plead specifically every ground of defence on which he or she relies, including:
any claim for relief against forfeiture, and
any claim for rectification, and
any claim for relief under the Contracts Review Act 1980,
and it is not sufficient for a defendant to merely state that he or she is in possession of the land (whether personally or by a tenant) and relies on that possession.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.16] r 14.16 Defendant’s pleading of contributory negligence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 14; DCR Part 9, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Defendant’s pleading of contributory negligence (cf SCR Part 15, rule 14; DCR Part 9, rule 10)

p.text: A defendant who relies on contributory negligence must plead specifically the contributory negligence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.17] r 14.17 New matter may be raised in pleading (cf SCR Part 15, rule 16; DCR Part 9, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: New matter may be raised in pleading (cf SCR Part 15, rule 16; DCR Part 9, rule 11)

p.text: A party may plead any matter even if the matter has arisen after the commencement of the proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [14.17.5] Matters arising after the commencement of proceedings

heading.title: Matters arising after the commencement of proceedings

p.text: The cause of action relied upon must be complete when the proceedings are commenced, and a “matter” within this rule does not include a cause of action that has arisen subsequently: Baldry v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 415 at 419 ; Eshelby v Federated European Bank [1932] 1 KB 254 ; Coutts and Co v Duntroon Investment Corp Ltd [1958] 1 All ER 51 at 53; [1958] 1 WLR 116 ; Warner v Sampson [1959] 1 QB 297 at 321; [1959] 1 All ER 120 ; Wigan v Edwards (1973) 1 ALR 497 at 515; 47 ALJR 586; BC7300039 . However, this does not prevent reliance on events related to the cause of action which occur after the commencement of proceedings. For example, an election to treat a contract as repudiated does not raise a new cause of action and may be made after the commencement of proceedings: Tilcon Ltd v Land and Real Estate Investments Ltd [1987] 1 All ER 615 at 620. Furthermore, a distinction exists between the original claim and defence on the one hand, and a cross-claim on the other. A cross-claim may be pleaded in respect of a cause of action that has arisen since the proceedings were commenced: Beddall v Maitland (1881) 17 Ch D 174 ; Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals v Consolidated Press Ltd (1952) 70 WN (NSW) 232 ; Crothers v Hire Finance Ltd (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 469 and Baldry v Jackson [1976] 2 NSWLR 415 at 419 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.18] r 14.18 Pleadings to be consistent as to allegations of fact (cf SCR Part 15, rule 17; DCR Part 9, rule 12)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings to be consistent as to allegations of fact (cf SCR Part 15, rule 17; DCR Part 9, rule 12)

p.text: A party must not in any pleading make an allegation of fact, or raise any ground or claim, inconsistent with any of his or her previous pleadings.
Subrule (1) does not affect the right of a party to make allegations of fact, or raise grounds or claims, in the alternative.

level.toc-caption: [14.18.5] Alternative, but not inconsistent, factual allegations

heading.title: Alternative, but not inconsistent, factual allegations

p.text: Parties cannot properly plead inconsistent factual allegations. For example, a reply alleging waiver of performance of conditions precedent is an impermissible departure from a statement of claim that alleges fulfillment of the condition: White v Derwent & Tamar Insurance Co (1888) 14 VLR 642 ; but see Davis v Dougall (1889) 15 VLR 424 at 427 ; Spicers and Detmold Ltd v Australian Automatic Cigarette Paper Co Pty Ltd [1942] VLR 97 . However, joinder of parties and making alternative allegations about them is entirely proper where there is doubt as to which of them is entitled to, or liable for, the relief claimed: Qantas Airways Ltd v AF Liddle Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 34 ; News Ltd v Australian Rugby Football League Ltd (1996) 64 FCR 410 at 523; 139 ALR 193; BC9604667 . Furthermore, a plaintiff may plead factual allegations in the alternative, even though the alternative allegations would otherwise be inconsistent: Re Morgan (1887) 35 Ch D 492 ; Re Smith (1884) 9 PD 68; Casey v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1981] 1 NSWLR 305 at 308. Similarly, a defendant may rely on alternative and grounds of defence: Re Morgan (1887) 35 Ch D 492 ; Coote v Ford [1899] 2 Ch 93 at 106 ; Moloney v Moloney (1903) 20 WN (NSW) 267 ; Laws v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1990) 170 CLR 70 at 85; 93 ALR 435; BC9002913 ; Peninsula and Oriental SN Co v Britnell (1892) 18 VLR 580 . For example, in the case of a claim for breach of contract, a defendant could properly both deny that there was an agreement and also say that if the court found that there was one then the plaintiff was itself in breach and liable to pay damages to the defendant: Peninsula and Oriental SN Co v Britnell, above. (Where the facts to support alternative allegations are essentially different, the facts should be specifically pleaded: Bohemia Crystal Pty Ltd v Swarovski 14 IPR 201; (1989) 95 FLR 46 at 60 .)

Neither the inconsistency of alternative factual allegations, nor their complexity, necessarily renders the pleading bad. The primary question is whether the alternative allegations cause embarrassment or inconvenience: Lamerand v Lamerand (No 2) [1962] NSWR 248; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 389 ; and see Norman v Corrigan (1916) 16 SR (NSW) 225 . The rule does not prohibit a party from using a subsequent pleading to explain or qualify an earlier pleading: South Suburban Land Co v Hughes (1889) 15 VLR 308 . And a pleading that contains alternative submissions about the legal effect of previously pleaded facts does not involve relevant inconsistency: Re Vandervell’s Trusts (No 2) [1974] Ch 269 . A pleading will be embarrassing if it relies on inconsistent allegations and one of them must be false to the knowledge of the pleader: Brailsford v Tobie (1889) 10 ALT 194 ; Issitch v Worrell (2000) 172 ALR 586 at [32] . Subject to that limitation, the requirement that pleadings be verified does not necessarily preclude the use of alternative factual allegations — an acceptable format for an affidavit verifying alternative allegations is, “Should it be held that... then the defendant says...”: see Fenton v Fenton [1966] 2 NSWR 605; (1966) 85 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 430 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.19] r 14.19 Pleadings may raise points of law (cf SCR Part 15, rule 18; DCR Part 9, rule 13)

leg:heading.title: Pleadings may raise points of law (cf SCR Part 15, rule 18; DCR Part 9, rule 13)

p.text: A pleading may raise any point of law.

If a question of law is raised, it should be taken clearly and explicitly: Stokes v Grant (1878) 4 CPD 25; Burrows v Rhodes [1899] 1 QB 816 at 818 . If the pleading raises a properly arguable question of law it will not be struck out: Tomkinson v South Eastern Railway Co (No 2) (1887) 57 LT 358 ; Hodges v New South Wales (1988) 77 ALR 1; 62 ALJR 190 . However, where all the facts pleaded are admitted and the only issue is a point of law, no evidence will be admitted at the trial: Pioneer Plastic Containers Ltd v Cmr of Customs and Excise [1967] Ch 597; [1967] 1 All ER 1053 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.20] r 14.20 Pleading the general issue (cf SCR Part 15, rule 27)

leg:heading.title: Pleading the general issue (cf SCR Part 15, rule 27)

p.text: A pleading may not plead the general issue.

Under the general issue, a defendant was able to make a general denial of the whole of the plaintiff’s case. The nature and effect of the general issue plea is explained in Commissioner for Government Transport v Brooks [1960] NSWR 772 at 774; (1960) 61 SR (NSW) 97 . As to the history of this rule, see Moore Road Machinery (NSW) Pty Ltd v Sourry [1960] NSWR 227; (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 554 and Rudenno v South Pacific Developments Pty Ltd [1968] 2 NSWR 716; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 538 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.21] r 14.21 Pleadings concerning claims under Property (Relationships) Act 1984

leg:heading.title: Pleadings concerning claims under Property (Relationships) Act 1984

p.text: A pleading with respect to a claim for relief under section 20(1) of the Property (Relationships) Act 1984 must plead specifically any contribution referred to in that subsection on which the plaintiff relies.
